RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 5 March 2019: A promising ISM lifts the dollar to a two-week high
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.
 

US MARKET WRAP 5 March 2019: A promising ISM lifts the dollar to a two-week high

* SNAP SHOT: Equities mixed, dollar up, treasuries up, crude up.

* REAR VIEW: Strong ISM figure, Dec New Home Sales beats, Fed’s Rosengren sees one 2019 hike, China NPC lowers target growth, Carney tilts hawkish, UK’s Cox & Barclay negotiating in Brussels,

* AHEAD: Australian GDP, US ADP National Employment & International Trade, Canadian Trade Balance, BoC Rate Decision, BoJ's Harada Speaking, BoE's Cunliffe, Haldane & Saunders Speaking, Fed's Williams Speaking, UK GBP 3bln 2024 Gilt Auction

 

* ISM NON-MFG: It was a mixed bag for the February non-manufacturing ISM, with the headline beating, though there was some disappointment with the sub-indices. Pantheon Macroeconomics says the data were previously impacted by the government shutdown as well as the stock slide in Q4, and therefore, a rebound was likely. "The reported plunge in December retail sales might have made some forecasters hold back, but we don’t believe the numbers and we expect them to be revised up substantially," Pantheon says, "the ISM data support our view that the much stronger Redbook chain store sales numbers more accurately reflect the strength of spending over the holidays," and "sales growth is now slowing, though, as the boost from the tax cuts and the drop in gas prices fades, so further sustained gains in the ISM non-manufacturing headline are unlikely." Ahead of Friday's NFP data, there was also some attention on the employment component, which slipped by over two points to 55.2. Pantheon still thinks that is solid, but it suggests that labour demand is now running at a 200k monthly clip vs the 250k+ that was signalled last summer/fall. "Labour supply could not keep up with demand at that pace, so the slowing in demand now, as the tax cuts fade, does not necessarily mean that payroll growth will materially soften," Pantheon says, "For now, though, what matters is the strong-looking headline, which should help offset some of the fears triggered by the aggressive manufacturing downshift."

* NEW HOME SALES (DEC): Although December new home sale printed a 3.7% rise - above the expected 8.7% fall - this was overshadowed by downward revisions to previous data. Analysts at Wells Fargo Economics highlight that “Sales ended the year just 1.5% ahead of 2017’s pace, the weakest annual gain since 2011.” The dwindling figures at the end of last year were most likely heavily induced by rising rates. However, following a rate reversal, “lower mortgage rates should fuel improvements in coming months.”

* FED: Fed's Rosengren (voter, hawk) said a rate hike should be on the table this year provided that the economy meets his outlook. Rosengren said that in the face of heightened risks, policymakers can be patient; risks to the outlook have increased recently. He adds that earlier concerns that the economy might overheat in a number of ways seem somewhat less pressing at this juncture, and that there is some risk that more pronounced slowdowns in the rest of the world could dampen US growth. Fed's Kaplan (non-voter, dove) said increasing US corporate debt is one factor in wanting patience on rates. Fed's Kashkari (non-voter, dove) says he is doing everything he can to avoid lifting rates, which he believes would end the expansion.

* BOC PREVIEW: BOC to keep rates on hold at 1.75%, analysts say. Rate decision 1500 GMT/1000 EST on 6 March 2019; statement-only meeting. Dep Gov Patterson will deliver the Economic Progress report the next day. Click here for the full RANsquawk preview.

* CHINA NPC: The NPC lowered the target growth for the year to 6-6.5% from 'around 6.5%', more or less in line with the consensus; China also announced further tax cuts and fiscal stimulus through infrastructure investments, and loans to small businesses. The deficit target was set at 2.8% of GDP (Street looked for somewhere between 2.6% and 3%); there were reiterations that monpol would be kept prudent.

* BREXIT: UK AG Cox and Brexit Sec Barclay were in Brussels today, attempting to renegotiate the Irish backstop proposal ahead of next week's series of Meaningful Votes in Parliament (12-14 March). Ahead of the meeting, two EU officials said that the UK is examining whether the 1969 Vienna Convention could provide any legal wiggle-room to engineer a deal. It was later reported that a UK official downplayed the chances of any deal coming from today's meeting, injecting a negative bias into GBP on Tuesday. Elsewhere, there were reports that the UK is to cut tariffs on imports in the event of a no-deal Brexit.

* BOE GOVERNOR CARNEY: The BoE’s Governor Carney caught the sterling market off guard on Tuesday, at a House of Lords hearing, where he said the bank’s rate path might not be high enough.

* WTI (J9) SETTLED USD 0.03 LOWER AT USD 56.56/BBL, BRENT (J9) SETTLED USD 0.19 HIGHER AT USD 65.86/BBL. Crude prices were mixed on Tuesday, where a slew of positive PMI data from Europe heightened risk appetite. However, prices pared back gains after the US equity open, where a recent trend has developed of equities selling off just as Europeans begin leaving their desks. Alongside the equity sell off, a strong ISM non-mfg headline figure saw a spike in the dollar, further leading to negative ticks in oil prices. On the supply side of the equation, Libya’s El Sharara oilfield production increased to 80k BPD from 30k BPD yesterday after the force majeure was lifted. The Venezuelan, state-owned PDVSA's Isla refinery (335k BPD) is reported to stay shut through 2019 due to sanctions. The market is looking ahead to tonight’s APIs to gauge energy inventories ahead of tomorrow’s official DOE release, following last week’s extreme crude stock draw of over 8mln bbls. Crude stocks are seen building by 1.2mln bbls, distillates drawing 1.4mln bbls and gasoline drawing 2.1mln bbls; Genscape forecasts the key Cushing, Oklahoma delivery hub building 373k bbls. This Friday the CFTC will release its COT data, which will finally be up to date following the US shutdown, although data has been laggard for WTI,  analysts at PVM note an “obvious trend” of how money managers have been favouring Brent in comparison to WTI recently, despite WTI’s recent rise, where “Brent speculators have added 130 million bbls to their net exposure this year whilst WTI financial investors have cut their net speculative length by 12mln bbls.”

* SPX -0.11% at 2790, NDX +0.08% at 7157, DJI -0.05% at 25807. SECTORS: Energy -0.32%, Materials -0.50%, Industrials -0.64%, Cons Discretionary +0.20%, Cons Staples -0.04%, Healthcare -0.07%, Financials -0.33%, Tech -0.29%, Telecoms +0.73%, Utilities -0.17%.

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: Some strong earnings from the retail sector on Tuesday: Target (TGT) surged on beating top and bottom line estimates as well as SSS expectations, it also raised guidance; Kohl’s (KSS) too surged on a top and bottom line beat as well as raising its guidance. Delta Air Lines (DAL) outperformed in the midst of the JPMorgan Aviation conference where it affirmed its earnings guidance; later on at the conference, General Electric (GE) tanked after announcing it would see negative industrial FCF in 2019. Salesforce (CRM) drifted lower despite beating EPS and revenue estimates, however it did not raise its guidance. Align Technology. Tesla (TSLA) dipped again, this time following reports of Chinese customs holding over 1,500 Tesla vehicles due to “improper labelling”. Ctrip (CTRP) made large gains after reporting a surprise profit. Hertz (HTZ) dropped after investor Carl Icahn lowered his stake. Alnylam (ALNY) benefitted from an upgrade at Morgan Stanley who are optimistic on its Opattro drug launch.

* US T-NOTE FUTURE (H9) SETTLES HALF-A-TICK HIGHER AT 121-22. The complex ends the day with yields a touch higher, partly on the back of a decent headline for the Feb ISM non-manufacturing survey, while some traders cited decent corporate earnings from Target (TGT) which pushed back on some data hinting at a slowdown in the retail sector. The developments helped shrug-off overnight 'risk-off' stories (China PMIs, China cutting growth). Major curve spreads were mixed heading into the close. 

* EUR: The EUR seems to be lacking any upside momentum initiative; UBS sales desk has also observed that the bounces too are shallow. The bank recommends keeping an eye on 1.1380 to the upside (coincides with a short-term downtrend line) and 1.1280 as the major support, and expects consolidation between those levels ahead of Thursday's ECB meeting.

* CHF: The Swissy has been more reticent to participate in the broader USD rally, with USDCHF confined to a narrow range while the Buck bounces. Despite some seeing the USDCHF as a 'cleaner' way to play USD short positions, while the dollar's trajectory is higher, some suggest that a USDCHF breakout ('catch up effect') is a risk. Today's inflation data leant a little to that hypothesis, with the Swissy trading weaker after an in line CPI report (0.4% MM, 0.6% YY). "The franc’s appreciation over the course of 2018 is likely to begin having an effect on the inflation rate," Commerzbank says, "Of course further franc appreciation would be very inconvenient for the SNB, and as a result it is keeping a close eye on developments in connection with Brexit," which could stoke a haven bid. So the SNB is conducting policy with one eye on external events; Commerz suggests that if the CHF appreciates too sharply, and too much, the SNB will resume intervention in FX with words or even actions. Accordingly, Commerz doesn't see EURCHF aking ground sub-1.10.

* JPY: Some desks have reported buying interest around 111.50 (and supports at the 100 and 200 DMA at 111.30 and 111.40, respectively), with sellers expected to show up around the 112.50 region. the pair moved through the 112.00 level, and breached the 112.08 (76.4% of the 114.55 to 104.10 fall). Above the aforementioned MAs now opens the door to the 2018 high around 114.55, technicians say.

* GBP: If you needed an instance to demonstrate how much attention GBP traders are paying to politics rather than fundamentals, then this was that day. UK services PMI put in an upside beat in February, and we also had some hawkish-leaning comments from BOE governor Carney, but GBP traded with a negative bias on the headline UK govt is said not to expect any breakthrough at the meeting between UK Attorney General Cox and EU Brexit negotiator Barnier at their meeting today.

* CAD: Ahead of tomorrow's BOC, CAD was taking its cue from the USD and oil prices, and softened back up to 1.3350. TD Securities says their base case is for a dovish hold, where the BOC reiterates that rates will move to neutral over time, which the bank thinks 1.3325 is the target for CAD; a dovish hold, where it would abandon the reference to higher rates for a neutral stance could open the door to 1.3460, TD says, and in the unlikely event that the BOC cuts rates, a breach of 1.36 could be on the cards. "We expect the BoC will leave the overnight rate unchanged in line with market expectations," TD says, "the communique is likely to have a dovish tilt to it, as the recent deterioration in economic data ought to outweigh the impact of higher oil prices," and the bank says the BOC will likely leave its forward looking language mostly unchanged, warning of higher policy rates over time subject to the evolution of the data." Full RANsquawk preview here.

* AUD: RBA overnight was unchanged, and there was little new info in its policy statement. The Aussie was also being dictated to by events in China (NPC and weak Caixin PMIs), while the US non-manufacturing ISM upside did little for the Antipode. Attention now shifts to Governor Lowe, who will be speaking at a business summit, while traders will also be keeping an eye on the Q4 GDP report.

* RUB: The Russian rouble has performed well, of late, supported by Brent prices above 60-64 range, and foreign investors have been scopping up OFZs. Some desks speculated that this could lead the CBR raising its FX purchases later in the month in order to put a lid on further RUB upside. And that is what we saw today, with the Finance Ministry announcing USD 4.7bln of purchases due in March (consensus was USD 3.7bln). "Combined with the backlog from 2H18, total FX purchases in March will reach USD 5.6bln," ING says. However, ING does not see this as a threat to the RUB in the short-term as a result of the USD 9bln to USD 10bln monthly current account in Q1 of 2019. That said, the bank says mid-term risks are rising.

* ZAR: South African GDP was a mixed bag, with the QQ print missing expectations, while the YY put in an upside surprise. The rand was happy to take the positives, and rallied against the buck (EMFX was generally seeing some upside, on the whole), but South African stocks didn't share the optimism, while bonds firmed. Nevertheless, some profit-taking was cited in the ZAR with buying interest loining up at the 14.10 level, according to reports. Key level to watch is the 200DMA sub-14.00, analysts said.

Some desks speculated that this could lead the CBR raising its FX purchases later in the month in order to put a lid on further RUB upside. And that is what we saw today, with the Finance Ministry announcing USD 4.7bln of purchases due in March (consensus was USD 3.7bln). "Combined with the backlog from 2H18, total FX purchases in March will reach USD 5.6bln," ING says. However, ING does not see this as a threat to the RUB in the short-term as a result of the USD 9bln to USD 10bln monthly current account in Q1 of 2019. That said, the bank says mid-term risks are rising.

* ZAR: South African GDP was a mixed bag, with the QQ print missing expectations, while the YY put in an upside surprise. The rand was happy to take the positives, and rallied against the buck (EMFX was generally seeing some upside, on the whole), but South African stocks didn't share the optimism, while bonds firmed. Nevertheless, some profit-taking was cited in the ZAR with buying interest lining up at the 14.10 level, according to reports. Key level to watch is the 200DMA sub-14.00, analysts said.

* MXN: Data showed Mexican consumer confidence rising for a third straight month to a record high in February, helping the MXN gain against the USD (DXY was up in the session). The data will provide some comfort to the new Administration who have been warned by rating agencies. For now this will put less pressure on the Banxico to pivot dovish; the central bank has been acting against high inflation, though as this eases and the data slate becomes softer, some have argued that the case for policy easing was becoming prominent (the latest Banxico survey of private sector expectations has seen lower estimates for both growth and inflation, for instance). Capital Economics has said that the Banxico's concerns on inflation, specifically core inflation, are somewhat overdone, noting that weaker food inflation over the coming quarters should push down core price pressure, and therefore, sees the easing cycle beginning in Q3 of this year, and the consultancy sees the Banciso cutting rates to 7.50% by year-end (from 8.25%).

analysis_details: Crude prices were mixed on Tuesday, where a slew of positive PMI data from Europe heightened risk appetite. However, prices pared back gains after the US equity open, where a recent trend has developed of equities selling off just as Europeans begin leaving their desks. Alongside the equity sell off, a strong ISM non-mfg headline figure saw a spike in the dollar, further leading to negative ticks in oil prices. On the supply side of the equation, Libya’s El Sharara oilfield production increased to 80k BPD from 30k BPD yesterday after the force majeure was lifted. The Venezuelan, state-owned PDVSA's Isla refinery (335k BPD) is reported to stay shut through 2019 due to sanctions. The market is looking ahead to tonight’s APIs to gauge energy inventories ahead of tomorrow’s official DOE release, following last week’s extreme crude stock draw of over 8mln bbls. Crude stocks are seen building by 1.2mln bbls, distillates drawing 1.4mln bbls and gasoline drawing 2.1mln bbls; Genscape forecasts the key Cushing, Oklahoma delivery hub building 373k bbls. This Friday the CFTC will release its COT data, which will finally be up to date following the US shutdown, although data has been laggard for WTI,  analysts at PVM note an “obvious trend” of how money managers have been favouring Brent in comparison to WTI recently, despite WTI’s recent rise, where “Brent speculators have added 130 million bbls to their net exposure this year whilst WTI financial investors have cut their net speculative length by 12mln bbls.”

subject: ANALYSIS: US ISM non-manufacturing index a mixed-bag in February
content: It was a mixed bag for the February non-manufacturing ISM, with the headline beating, though there was some disappointment with the sub-indices. Pantheon Macroeconomics says the data were previously impacted by the government shutdown as well as the stock slide in Q4, and therefore, a rebound was likely. "The reported plunge in December retail sales might have made some forecasters hold back, but we don’t believe the numbers and we expect them to be revised up substantially," Pantheon says, "the ISM data support our view that the much stronger Redbook chainstore sales numbers more accurately reflect the strength of spending over the holidays," and "sales growth is now slowing, though, as the boost from the tax cuts and the drop in gas prices fades, so further sustained gains in the ISM non-manufacturing headline are unlikely." Ahead of Friday's NFP data, there was also some attention on the employment component, which slipped by over two points to 55.2. Pantheon still thinks that is solid, but i sugests that labour demand is now running at a 200k monthly clip vs the 250k+ that was signalled last summer/fall. "Labor supply could not keep up with demand at that pace, so the slowing in demand now, as the tax cuts fade, does not necessarily mean that payroll growth will materially soften," Pantheon says, "For now, though, what matters is the the strong-looking headline, which should help offset some of the fears triggered by the aggressive manufacturing downshift."

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Sterling battered as Brexit optimism falls flat
content:
GBP

The Pound has lost even more of its recent bullish Brexit premium as rising hopes of support for PM May’s Withdrawal Agreement fade further amidst reports that latest negotiations in Brussels will not produce the assurances needed to convince doubters and opposers to back the deal when it goes before Parliament again. In fact, even the UK Government is not anticipating a breakthrough when AG Cox meets EU’s Barnier, although there will be detailed negotiations about potential changes to the current backstop proposal. Cable took out another series of downside technical ‘supports’, like the 10 DMA and a Fib on its way through another big figure at 1.1300, but held just above a late February low and then retested the aforementioned 1.3130 Fib as the Usd lost some momentum around 97.000 in DXY terms. Meanwhile, EUR/Gbp rebounded to just shy of 0.8650 from 0.8585 at one stage, as the single currency remained a bit more resilient on the back of above forecast and/or flash Eurozone PMIs, and an unexpected (but welcome) upward revision to final Italian Q4 GDP. However, Eur/Usd eventually lost grip of 1.1300 handle and is becoming increasingly vulnerable from a chart perspective while under 1.1350.

NZD/CAD 

The other major laggards after the overnight miss in China’s Caixin services PMI and the NPC’s official growth downgrade, with the Kiwi extending losses vs its US counterpart below 0.6800 to 0.6775 and the Loonie unable to stem the tide from 1.3350+ vs the Usd for long as Canadian-Chinese tensions were underlined by the blocking of Canola imports by Beijing. Back to Nzd/Usd, the latest GDT auction results may provide some independent direction, but for the record the event has not been an NZ driver for a while.

CHF/AUD/JPY 

All ending Tuesday’s EU session on the backfoot vs the Buck that derived extra traction from an upbeat US non-manufacturing ISM survey to nudge the index incrementally over the next round number as noted above. Usd/Chf rebounded further above 1.0000 to 1.0040 and Aud/Usd got very close to hefty 1.6 bn option expiries at 0.7050, while Usd/Jpy seems to have cleared 112.00 resistance and psychological offers more convincingly to test a Fib just above.

SEK 

A rare if note sole G10 winner, albeit vs the Eur as Sweden’s services PMI surprised to the upside and helped pull the cross back under 10.6000 to 10.5450 at one stage.

subject: Fed's Rosengren (voter) says in the face of heightened risks, policymakers can be patient, risks to that outlook have increased recently
content:
• Says many of the underlying global growth issues that generated the recent spate of financial-market concerns are as yet unresolved
  • There is some risk that more pronounced slowdowns in the rest of the world could dampen US growth
  • Earlier concerns that the economy might overheat in a number of ways seem somewhat less pressing at this juncture
  • Together these factors are sufficient to justify a pause in the recent monetary tightening cycle
  • Rosengren forecasts a "relatively strong" economy in 2019, sees growth somewhat above 2 percent, inflation close to the Fed’s 2 percent target, and a labor market that continues to tighten

subject: Nomura Quants say stock buying in recent days has been carried out rapidly in an 'exuberant' manner
content:
• The US stock market tumbled sharply after continuously edging higher into an overheated state," Nomura says, "therefore, when S&P500, for example, breached above ~2,800, selling pressure from profit-taking by market participants wary of a short term return reversal may have expanded temporarily."
  • The bank also says that the recent rise in long-term UST yields has stressed high-valuation names like small-caps. "Of course, Monday's market correction appears technically driven," Nomura says, "and we cannot yet confirm an observable deterioration of US equity market sentiment."
  • But Nomura says "since stock buying in recent days has been carried out rapidly in an 'exuberant' manner, there may be some skeptical light-footed players positioning on the sustainability of the market rally," adding that "with the US stock market forming a relatively large dip in its high price range, some may quickly close their positions."
  • According to Nomura’s real-time estimate, "CTA net long positions on S&P500 futures continue to level off, but their positions on Russell 2000 futures as well as Nasdaq100 futures have been reduced somewhat." In addition, Nomura says "a seasonal pattern of VVIX (i.e., volatility of VIX) suggest now is a time for market volatility to rise to some extent."
  • Nomura now looks for the stock market to experience "counter vailing forces of those selling for early profit-taking and those buying on dips," and says we should note that the breakeven or average entry cost of S&P500 for CTA existing net long positions accumulated since February is estimated at ~2,750, so systematic selling pressures forcutting their 'loss-making' positions will heighten with a fall in the S&P500 of 2% or more.
  • Nomura also observes a market pattern where the major risky assets have been rapidly recovering to conditions last seen at end-November 2018. "In other words, the Street’s hope for the US-China trade agreement that had nearly disappeared at end-November has revived since February," and based on that, the bank judges "that the S&P500 and other major risk asset prices have come back to points close their levels at end-November.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 5th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Major European indices are moving towards negative territory, after starting the session somewhat firmer [Euro Stoxx 50 U/C]
  • China lowered their 2019 GDP growth target range to 6.0-6.5% vs. Prev. around 6.5%
  • DXY is off of its best levels, but continues to move higher and as such is outperforming its G10 counterparts
  • Looking ahead, highlights US Composite and Services PMI, US ISM Non-Manufacturing PMI, Fed’s Rosengren, Kashkari, Barkin, BoE’s Carney, RBA’s Lowe

ASIA

Asian stocks traded lacklustre following a disappointing lead from Wall Street after the Dow slipped 0.8%, weighed on by Boeing and Goldman Sachs shares, whilst the S&P shed 0.4% amid underperformance in healthcare names. Both indices marked their worst turnaround since early February. ASX 200 (-0.3%) extended losses from the open amid underperformance in the Consumer Discretionary and Material sectors, whilst Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) was weighed on by commodity exposed stocks. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) nursed some opening losses following the release of the NPC work report which pledged to expand infrastructure investments and cut manufacturing VAT to 13% from 16%, whilst transport and construction VAT is to be reduced to 9% from 10%, although the release of dismal Caixin services PMI briefly dented the index. Finally, Hang Seng (U/C) conformed to the overall risk-averse tone with its heavy-weight financial sector as the marked underperformer.

China lowered its 2019 GDP growth target to the range of 6.0-6.5% from “around 6.5%” and maintained CPI target at 3.0%, both as expected. Budget deficit for 2019 was set at 2.8% vs. 2.6% in 2018. China stated that fiscal policy to be proactive and monetary policy to be prudent will not resort to flood-like stimulus, whilst also saying it will keep the Yuan basically stable at reasonable equilibrium and is to increase the flexibility of the Yuan exchange rate while keeping liquidity reasonably ample. China will expand infrastructure investments in 2019 and plans to cut manufacturing VAT to 13% from 16%, as touted, VAT for transport and construction sectors to be reduced to 9% from prior 10%. China will make economic policy for forward-looking, targeted and effective whilst maintaining pace and strength in risk prevention, and higher budget deficit ration will leave more policy room for resolving potential risks. China will also step up targeted RRR cuts for smaller and medium-sized banks to support private and smaller firms. Growth in M2 Money Supply and social financial to be in-line with nominal GDP growth and basically the same as in 2018. China is to implement consensus reached between US and Chinese leaders in Argentina, but said it needs to brace for a tough economic battle.

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6998 (Prev. 6.7049) (Newswires)
PBoC drained a net CNY 120bln on the day

Chinese Caixin Services PMI Feb 51.1 vs. Exp. 53.5 (Prev. 53.6) (Newswires)
Chinese Caixin Composite PMI Feb 50.7 (Prev. 50.9)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said he believes US and China are “on the cusp” of a deal to end a trade war. (Newswires)

US President Trump plans to terminate India and Turkey as Generalised System of Preferences beneficiaries. The move comes as India has not assured the US that it will provide "equitable and reasonable" market access and Turkey is now “sufficiently economically developed”; according to US Trade officials. Indian Trade Ministry Official, in response, said US and India were able to work out an extensive and reasonable package which covered almost all US concerns, although the advantages under the US GSP are "minimal and moderate". (Newswires)

US

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin has urged Congress to lift the debt limit as soon as possible and added that the new debt issuance suspension will be from March 4th to June 5th. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau has accepted the resignation of Treasury Board Minister Philpott and names Qualtrough as acting Treasury Board President; according to a statement from the PM's office. (Newswires)

Chinese hackers have reportedly targeted Universities in the US, seeking maritime secrets (WSJ)

GEOPOLITICAL

Rail services between India and Pakistan have now resumed after being halted amid the recent conflict; according to Indian press. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM May has been warned that she must whip her MPs to keep a no-deal Brexit on the table, whilst Senior Eurosceptics are convinced PM May will lose the vote on her Brexit deal and they do not expect Attorney General Cox to win concessions on the Northern Irish backstop. (The Telegraph)

UK PM May is reportedly considering a parliamentary vote on the UK's future relationship with the EU, as per demands from Labour MPs. A source close to a cabinet minister also stated that there seemed to be “no chance” that her deal would pass next week. (The Guardian)

UK Trade Secretary Fox’s department has cancelled its regular meetings with business after the details of a prior meeting were leaked to the media. (FT)

Bank of England state the core of UK financial systems are ready for worst case scenario Brexit, and most stability risks mitigated. (Newswires)

UK BRC Retail Sales YY Feb -0.1% (Prev. 1.8%) (Newswires)

Italy will implement more expansive policies and increase deficit if international growth deteriorates, according to the Head of Senate Finance Committee Bagnai. Adding that it would be difficult for the European Commission to sanction Italy if Rome raised the deficit to manage the economic slowdown. (Newswires)

Italian undersecretary Buffagni says the 5 star movement are prepared to quit the ruling coalition over the Turin-Lyon high speed rail. (Newswires) Follows reports that the EU are planning to cancel EUR 300mln in funding for the Turin-Lyon high speed rail as there have been prolonged delays; if new project tenders are not launched by the end of the month.

Riksbank's Skingsley says they struggle to understand the recent developments of the SEK, and don't think changes in macro-space justify SEK weakness. Still sees a rate hike as possible if inflation dips below 2% target. (Newswires)

ECB says that they and the BoE will activate a currency swap arrangement for potential provision of EUR to UK banks, Eurosystem would stand ready to lend GBP to Euro Area Banks, if necessary. (Newswires)

EU Markit Services Final PMI (Feb) 52.8 vs. Exp. 52.3 (Prev. 52.3)

- EU Markit Comp Final PMI (Feb) 51.9 vs. Exp. 51.4 (Prev. 51.4)

- Italian Markit/IHS Services PMI (Feb) 50.4 vs. Exp. 49.4 (Prev. 49.7)

- French Markit Comp PMI (Feb) 50.4 vs. Exp. 49.9 (Prev. 49.9)

- French Markit Services PMI (Feb) 50.2 vs. Exp. 49.8 (Prev. 49.8)

- UK Markit/CIPS Services PMI (Feb) 51.3 vs. Exp. 49.9 (Prev. 50.1)

EQUITIES

Major European indices are moving towards negative territory, after starting the session somewhat firmer [Euro Stoxx 50 U/C] moving more in-line with the relatively poor performance seen overnight in Asia which was dictated largely by a disappointing lead from Wall Street. Sectors are mixed, with some slight underperformance in consumer discretionaries; the sector is weighed on by poor performance in Daimler (-0.8%), which represents around 7% of the sectors weighting, who are in the red after executives at the Co. stated they may have to lift prices to pass on potential US tariffs. Other notable movers include, Evonik (+3.8%) who are at the top of the Stoxx 600 after earnings where they beat on Q4 revenue. At the other end of the Stoxx 600, and weighed on by broker moves, are Altice (-9.1%) as are Richemont (-3.2%), who were both downgraded at Barclays and BOFA Merrill Lynch respectively. Elsewhere, Vodafone (+1.9%) are higher after after the Co. state they intend to raise around EUR 4bln through sterling denominated MCBS and there is the potential for a share buyback as part of this. Separately, British American Tobacco (+1.0%) are higher as the Co. state there will be no impact from the Quebec charge to their ratio of adj. net debt to adj. EBITDA.

FX

DXY - Off best levels, but the index continues to edge higher and just surpassed another chart resistance level (96.784) ahead of the next big figure on its way to a 96.815 high. The Greenback is still benefiting from weakness in rival currencies to an extent if not large part, or by default as a combination of negative/bearish factors inflict damage elsewhere (ranging from weaker macro fundamentals relative to the US, geopolitical instability/uncertainty and Central Bank policies aligning to Fed patience or even turning more dovish in certain cases, to name just a few). The DXY is now holding around 96.750 and well above Monday’s 96.331 low.

NZD/CAD - The 2 biggest G10 losers, with the Kiwi slipping below 0.6800 amidst a broader fall-out in risk currencies following a considerably weaker than forecast Chinese Caixin services PMI and confirmation that the NPC has downgraded its GDP sights to 6-6.5% from 6.5% previously. Meanwhile, the Loonie has extended recent losses to fresh multi-month lows circa 1.3350 vs its US counterpart with the added weight of heightened strains between Canada and China, plus another downturn in crude prices.

EUR/AUD/JPY/CHF - Also weaker vs Usd, as the single currency fails to derive much/any real support from surprise beats and upward tweaks to the Eurozone services PMIs, including the Italian headline that rebounded over 50.0 and was supplemented by an unexpected Q4 GDP revision to -0.1% q/q from -0.2%. Eur/Usd is hovering just above yesterday’s 1.1309 base and Fib support at 1.1305, but looks technically weak after breaching 1.1350 and key chart levels not far above. Similarly, the Aussie is struggling to mount a concerted recovery from recent lows towards 0.7100 after a dovish RBA policy statement on balance and yet more poor data overnight (Q4 net exports), and Aud/Usd could become increasingly drawn to a hefty option expiry down at 0.7050 as a result (1.6 bn). Meanwhile, the Yen and Franc continue to trade defensively on constructive US-China trade deal vibes, with Usd/Jpy edging back up to 112.00 and Usd/Chf straddling parity. Note also, decent option expiries in Usd/Jpy may impact into the NY cut, with 1 bn running off between 111.80-90 and 1.9 bn at the 112.00 strike.

GBP/SEK - Relative outperformers on better than expected UK and Swedish services PMIs vs other more downbeat economic indicators. However, Cable remains capped ahead of 1.3200 and the 100 WMA (1.3207), with the 10 DMA (1.3161) and a Fib (1.3130) now flanking the pair as it pivots 1.3150 awaiting any further Brexit developments. Eur/Sek has retreated through 10.6000 again and retesting bids around 10.5500.

EM - More angst for the Try and Inr after the US pulled the GSP plug from both nations, with the Lira attempting to pare losses and stay above 5.4000, but the Rupee staging a firmer recovery from almost 71.0000 at one stage as India’s Trade Ministry downplayed the impact of the trade pact being terminated.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds have now reversed through nearest downside tech support to test the next level around 165.28 that stands in front of 165.00 and Monday’s Eurex base (165.01), and a clean sweep of above forecast Eurozone services PMIs are an obvious catalyst for the deeper retreat. However, the rebound in Italian debt futures is also compelling as BTPs gleaned additional support from an unexpected upward tweak to Q4 GDP, a deal with the EU to extend guarantees for NPLs and a warning that the 5-Star party could quit the coalition over the Turin-Lyon rail link, thereby potentially removing a more contentious element from Government. Bunds now just off a new 165.26 low (-33 ticks on the day), BTPs not far from 128.86 at best (+44 ticks) and Gilts also seeing more retracement to 125.90 (-13 ticks) before rebounding firmly to post a marginal new Liffe high at 126.08 in spite of a significantly better than expected UK Service PMI.

Elsewhere, US Treasuries are back in bear steepening mode amidst more heavy sovereign/corporate supply and ahead of the non-manufacturing PMI.

COMMODITIES 

Brent (+0.2%) and WTI (+0.1%) prices are firmer although they were initially weighed on by the deteriorating risk tone, and Chinese Caixin Services PMI coming in below expectations at 51.1 vs. Exp. 53.5; with the complex also affected by dollar strength. Elsewhere, the El Sharara oil field has reopened at a current output of 30k BPD, far below the field’s capacity of around 300k BPD; although NOC has stated that a return to regular output is expected in the next few days. Looking ahead we have API Weekly release later in the session, which last week saw crude stocks fall by -4.2mln.

Gold (-0.1%) is relatively unchanged with the metal affected by both the stronger dollar and the deterioration in the risk tone seen overnight. Elsewhere, metals were weighed on by China lowering its GDP growth target to 6.0-6.5% from the prior of around 6.5%. Separately, the amount of copper available in LME system, fell to the lowest level since 2005 of 21.6k tonnes.

Libya's NOC said it has lifted the force majeure at the El Sharara oilfield (300k BPD); production has resumed at 30K BPD but is expected to reach 80K BPD in one day; according to sources. (Newswires)

content: Bunds have now reversed through nearest downside tech support to test the next level around 165.28 that stands in front of 165.00 and Monday’s Eurex base (165.01), and a clean sweep of above forecast Eurozone services PMIs are an obvious catalyst for the deeper retreat. However, the rebound in Italian debt futures is also compelling as BTPs gleaned additional support from an unexpected upward tweak to Q4 GDP, a deal with the EU to extend guarantees for NPLs and a warning that the 5-Star party could quit the coalition over the Turin-Lyon rail link, thereby potentially removing a more contentious element from Government. Bunds now just off a new 165.26 low (-33 ticks on the day), BTPs not far from 128.86 at best (+44 ticks) and Gilts also seeing more retracement to 125.90 (-13 ticks) just ahead of the UK services PMI.

subject: Bunds: somewhat betwixt and between
content: The core Eurozone bond has drifted down from initial/early Eurex peaks of 165.67/68 to a 165.49 low vs Monday’s 165.59 close in line with the mildly weaker tone in US Treasuries and JGBs, but the 10 year German debt future remains well off yesterday’s lows and cushioned by more pronounced selling pressure in BTPs as certain Italian officials seem intent on pushing the fiscal boundaries further if the need arises, just ahead of the final read of Q4 GDP. However, Bunds and other Eurex contracts are also still the throes of position rolling from March to June and this could distort price action as attention turns to the services PMIs and retail sales.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 5th March 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian stocks traded lacklustre following a disappointing lead from Wall Street. Mainland China maintained composure following the Chinese NPC announcement
  • China lowered its 2019 GDP growth target to the range of 6.0-6.5% from “around 6.5%” and maintained CPI target at 3.0%, both as expected, budget deficit for 2019 was set at 2.8% vs. 2.6% in 2018
  • The RBA left its Cash Rate unchanged at 1.50% as expected. The statement was relatively mixed but the last paragraph (often seen as the most important) remained unchanged
  • In FX markets, DXY gained more ground, AUD was dented by China Caixin Services PMI, TRY weakened on Trump’s GSP termination
  • Looking ahead, highlights include French, German, EZ (Final) & US Composite and Services PMI, EZ Retail Sales, US ISM Non-Manufacturing PMI, Fed’s Rosengren, Kashkari, Barkin, BoE’s Carney, RBA’s Lowe

ASIA-PAC

Asian stocks traded lacklustre following a disappointing lead from Wall Street after the Dow slipped 0.8%, weighed on by Boeing and Goldman Sachs shares, whilst the S&P shed 0.4% amid underperformance in healthcare names. Both indices marked their worst turnaround since early February. ASX 200 (-0.3%) extended losses from the open amid underperformance in the Consumer Discretionary and Material sectors, whilst Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) was weighed on by commodity exposed stocks. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (Unch) nursed some opening losses following the release of the NPC work report which pledged to expand infrastructure investments and cut manufacturing VAT to 13% from 16%, whilst transport and construction VAT is to be reduced to 9% from 10%, although the release of dismal Caixin services PMI briefly dented the index. Finally, Hang Seng (-0.2%) conformed to the overall risk-averse tone with its heavy-weight financial sector as the marked underperformer.

China lowered its 2019 GDP growth target to the range of 6.0-6.5% from “around 6.5%” and maintained CPI target at 3.0%, both as expected. Budget deficit for 2019 was set at 2.8% vs. 2.6% in 2018. China stated that fiscal policy to be proactive and monetary policy to be prudent will not resort to flood-like stimulus, whilst also saying it will keep the Yuan basically stable at reasonable equilibrium and is to increase the flexibility of the Yuan exchange rate while keeping liquidity reasonably ample. China will expand infrastructure investments in 2019 and plans to cut manufacturing VAT to 13% from 16%, as touted, VAT for transport and construction sectors to be reduced to 9% from prior 10%. China will make economic policy for forward-looking, targeted and effective whilst maintaining pace and strength in risk prevention, and higher budget deficit ration will leave more policy room for resolving potential risks. China will also step up targeted RRR cuts for smaller and medium-sized banks to support private and smaller firms. Growth in M2 Money Supply and social financial to be in-line with nominal GDP growth and basically the same as in 2018. China is to implement consensus reached between US and Chinese leaders in Argentina, but said it needs to brace for a tough economic battle.

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.6998 (Prev. 6.7049) (Newswires)
PBoC drained a net CNY 120bln on the day

Chinese Caixin Services PMI Feb 51.1 vs. Exp. 53.5 (Prev. 53.6) (Newswires)
Chinese Caixin Composite PMI Feb 50.7 (Prev. 50.9)

US Secretary of State Pompeo said he believes US and China are “on the cusp” of a deal to end a trade war. (Newswires)

US President Trump plans to terminate India and Turkey as Generalised System of Preferences beneficiaries. The move comes as India has not assured the US that it will provide "equitable and reasonable" market access and Turkey is now “sufficiently economically developed”; according to US Trade officials. Indian Trade Ministry Official, in response, said US and India were able to work out an extensive and reasonable package which covered almost all US concerns, although the advantages under the US GSP are "minimal and moderate". (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM May has been warned that she must whip her MPs to keep a no-deal Brexit on the table, whilst Senior Eurosceptics are convinced PM May will lose the vote on her Brexit deal and they do not expect Attorney General Cox to win concessions on the Northern Irish backstop. (The Telegraph)

UK PM May is reportedly considering a parliamentary vote on the UK's future relationship with the EU, as per demands from Labour MPs. A source close to a cabinet minister also stated that there seemed to be “no chance” that her deal would pass next week. (The Guardian)

UK Trade Secretary Fox’s department has cancelled its regular meetings with business after the details of a prior meeting were leaked to the media. (FT)

Irish Foreign Minister Coveney is floating the idea of a "technical extension" to complete the ratification of the Withdrawal Agreement, as according to Sky's Reilly. (Newswires)

UK BRC Retail Sales YY Feb -0.1% (Prev. 1.8%) (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, the DXY gained more ground and briefly breached 96.750 to the upside, around 2-week highs, after recouping recent losses from US President Trump’s verbal intervention. As such EUR/USD languished further below the 1.1350 level whilst GBP/USD gave up more ground below its 100 WMA at 1.3207 before finding support at 1.3150. Elsewhere, AUD/USD was knocked lower after the China Caixin Services release showed that the measure for backlogs of work contracted for the second consecutive month, hitting its lowest level since February 2016 and in turn, reflecting downward pressure on overall orders. AUD/USD fell further below the 0.7100 and took the NZD down in sympathy. The Aussie experienced volatility at the release of the RBA statement but ultimately stabilised around pre-release levels as traders noted that the overall picture drawn by the Central Bank was little changed. In the EM FX space, TRY initially weakened on the back of reports that US President Trump is to drop Turkey’s long-standing preferential status when trading with the US against the backstop of strained relations between the US President and his Turkish counterpart. Furthermore, INR opened weaker amid Trump’s Generalised System of Preferences termination, but then pared losses after an Indian Trade Ministry official downplayed the consequences of deal ending. Finally, since February 25, Morgan Stanley positioning has shifted and within G10, the largest shorts are now in the CAD and CHF, whilst there are no significant longs, but JPY remains closest to long.

The RBA left its Cash Rate unchanged at 1.50% as expected. The statement which followed was digested as being relatively mixed but the last paragraph (often looked to as the most important) was unchanged. The statement noted that the slower pace of domestic growth has continued into 2019 whilst acknowledging the outlook for global growth remains a source of uncertainty and downside risks have increased. RBA said inflation remains low and stable and underlying inflation is expected to pick up over the next couple of years, with the pick-up likely to be gradual and to take a little longer than earlier expected. However, it highlighted that low level of interest rates continues to support the Australian economy and further progress in reducing unemployment and having inflation return to target is expected, although this progress is likely to be gradual.

Australian Current Account Balance SA Q4 -7.2B vs. Exp. -9.2B (Prev. -10.7B, Rev. -10.8B) (Newswires)
Australian Net Exports Contribution Q4 -0.2% vs. Exp. -0.1% (Prev. 0.4%)

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures were lower during Asia-Pac trade as the energy complex conformed to the risk tone, rising Dollar and disappointing Chinese data. WTI futures stabilised below USD 56.50/bbl while the global benchmark lost the USD 65.50/bbl level in early trade. In terms of metals, spot gold steadied near 5-week lows despite a rising greenback amid the risk averse mood, whilst Shanghai base metal futures fell after China lowered its GDP growth target to 6.0-6.5% from “around 6.5%”. Thus, Shanghai nickel retreated from 5-month highs despite a decline in stocks and Shanghai copper fell as much as 1.5%.

Libya's NOC said it has lifted the force majeure at the El Sharara oilfield (300k BPD); production has resumed at 30K BPD but is expected to reach 80K BPD in one day; according to sources. (Newswires)

India raised its gold holdings by 6.532 tonnes to 606.992 tonnes in Jan; China raised its by 11.82 tonnes to 1,864.39 tonnes in Jan; according to IMF data. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said military drills were not discussed at talks with North Korea's Leader Kim. (Newswires)

Rail services between India and Pakistan have now resumed after being halted amid the recent conflict; according to Indian press. (Newswires)

French President Macron said foreign powers should be banned from financing European political parties; calls for a European defence and security treaty to define obligations of EU members in coordination with NATO. (Newswires)

NORTH AMERICA

The US Treasury curve was flatter on Monday's trade, despite a heavy corporate supply docket for the week, where USD 40bln of corporate issuance is on tap, with USD 110-130bln expected through the course of March, analysts estimate. Real money was said to be putting through blocks on the long-end, taking cash yields down by around 3.5bps at settlement.

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin has urged Congress to lift the debt limit as soon as possible and added that the new debt issuance suspension will be from March 4th to June 5th. (Newswires)

US House Judiciary Committee issues document requests to 81 agencies, entities and individuals in Trump probe focused on alleged obstruction, corruption and other abuses of power. (Newswires) US lawmakers requested documents and interviews on Trump's communications with Russian President Putin. (Newswires)

US House Speaker Pelosi said congressional Democrats are to unveil new legislation on Wednesday to reinstate US net neutrality rules that were repealed by the Trump administration. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau has accepted the resignation of Treasury Board Minister Philpott and names Qualtrough as acting Treasury Board President; according to a statement from the PM's office. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MID SESSION UPDATE: Antipodeans dented as China’s services gauge indicate weakest growth in four months
content:
Asian stocks trade lacklustre following a disappointing lead from Wall Street after the Dow slipped 0.8%, weighed on by Boeing and Goldman Sachs shares, whilst the S&P shed 0.4% amid underperformance in healthcare names. Both indices marked their worst turnaround since early February. ASX 200 (-0.7%) extended losses from the open amid underperformance in the Consumer Discretionary and Material sectors, whilst Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) is weighed on by commodity exposed stocks. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) nursed some opening losses following the release of the NPC work report which pledged to expand infrastructure investments and cut manufacturing VAT to 13% from 16%, whilst transports and constructions VAT is to be reduced to 9% from 10%, although the release of dismal Caixin services PMI briefly dented the index. Finally, Hang Seng (-0.6%) has conformed to the overall risk-averse tone with its heavy-weight Financials sector as the marked underperformer.

In FX markets, the Dollar index stabilised after recouping recent losses as investors side-lined US President Trump’s verbal intervention. As such EUR/USD languished below the 1.1350 level whilst GBP/USD failed to nurse recent losses after falling below its 100 WMA at 1.3207. Elsewhere, AUD/USD was knocked lower after the China Caixin Services release showed that the measure for backlogs of work contracted for the second consecutive month, hitting its lowest level since February 2016 and in turn, reflecting downward pressure on overall orders. AUD/USD fell further below the 0.7100 and took the Kiwi down in sympathy ahead of the RBA rate decision. In the EM FX space, TRY initially weakened after reports that US President Trump is to drop Turkey’s long-standing preferential status when trading with the US against the backstop of strained relations between the US President and his Turkish counterpart.

content:
OTHER NEWS

- China sets 2019 GDP growth target at 6.0-6.5% (vs. Prev. “around 6.5%) and CPI at 3.0% as expected; fiscal policy to be proactive and monetary policy to be prudent. China targets a steady rise in trade and sets budget deficit at 2.8% of GDP vs. 2.6% in 2018. China said it will expand infrastructure investments in 2019 and will step up targeted RRR cuts for smaller and medium-sized banks to support private and smaller firms. China plans to cut manufacturing VAT to 13% from 16%, as touted earlier in the session and VAT for transport and construction sectors to be reduced to 9% from prior 10%. (Newswires)
